choices.text: Autosomal dominant condition due to mutation of the APC gene
More than 50 colonic adenomas are diagnostic
The lifetime risk of colorectal cancer is up to 100%
In a patient where the rectum is spared, total colectomy and ileorectal anastomosis can be considered as a treatment modality

questions.text: Given below is a picture showing multiple polyps in a patient with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP). Which of the following statements regarding FAP is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) More than 50 colonic adenomas are diagnostic

 

Option B:

 

FAP is defined clinically by the presence of more than 100 colorectal adenomas but is also characterized by duodenal adenomas and multiple extra-intestinal manifestations.

 

This statement is not true as the diagnosis of FAP typically requires the presence of over 100 colorectal adenomas.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Autosomal dominant condition due to mutation of the APC gene - This is accurate as FAP is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner with mutations in the APC gene leading to the condition.

 

Option C: The lifetime risk of colorectal cancer is up to 100% - This is correct, as individuals with FAP almost invariably develop colorectal cancer if the colon is not removed.

 

Option D: In a patient where the rectum is spared, total colectomy and ileorectal anastomosis can be considered as a treatment modality - This is a true statement, as ileorectal anastomosis is an option for patients with FAP who have rectal sparing, though it necessitates careful surveillance of the remaining rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In FAP, diagnosis requires over 100 adenomatous polyps, and while total colectomy with ileo-rectal anastomosis is a treatment option, regular monitoring of the rectum is essential due to the risk of malignancy.

 

  • The aim of surgery in FAP is to prevent the development of colorectal cancer. The surgical options are:

  1. Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouchâ€“anal anastomosis;

  2. Colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA);

  3. Total proctocolectomy and end-ileostomy.

 

NOTE: For patients with relative rectal sparing (<20 polyps), total colectomy and IRA is an option to be considered, particularly as it is associated with less risk of sexual dysfunction in males and less infertility in females. However, the rectum requires regular endoscopic surveillance as up to 10% of patients will develop invasive malignancy in the rectum. 

 

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed., pg 1357

choices.text: Genetic testing for APC gene mutation
Genetic testing for KRAS/BRAF gene mutation
Routine flexible sigmoidoscopy starting from 10 years of age
Routine flexible colonoscopy starting from 20 years of age

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was recently diagnosed for familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. He has an 8-year-old child. The family knows that FAP will increase the risk of colorectal cancers significantly; they have agreed to get screened. Which modality will you use for screening?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genetic testing for APC gene mutation

 

Option A:

 

  • The initial step in screening the child for familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome is to perform genetic testing for APC gene mutation. If screening is positive, flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy is done annually starting from 10 years of age.

 

This is the appropriate first step for the child of a patient with FAP. It identifies the presence of the APC gene mutation that causes FAP.

 

Explanations:
 

Option B: Testing for KRAS/BRAF gene mutations is not routinely performed for FAP screening as these are not the primary genes associated with FAP.

 

Option C: Sigmoidoscopy can be initiated at age 10 if the genetic test is positive, or even if it's negative but there is a strong family history, for regular surveillance.

 

Option D: Routine colonoscopy is typically started later in adolescence unless there are symptoms or a positive genetic test indicating higher risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic testing for the APC gene mutation is the recommended initial screening step for children at risk for familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome.

 

  • Polyps are usually visible on sigmoidoscopy by the age of 15 years and will almost always be visible by the age of 30 years. Regular endoscopic surveillance in a suspected family member should therefore commence at the age of 12–14 years, even if a genetic mutation has not been identified.
  • If the diagnosis is made during adolescence, surgery (prophylactic proctocolectomy) is usually deferred to the age of 17 or 18 years unless symptoms develop earlier.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1356

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors of colon cancer except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Human papilloma virus

 

Option D:

 

Human papilloma virus (HPV) is associated with anal canal and cervical cancers, but it is not a recognized risk factor for colon cancer.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: Ulcerative colitis is known to be associated with an increased risk of colon cancer due to chronic inflammation of the colon.

 

Option B: There is some evidence to suggest that cholecystectomy may marginally increase the risk of right-sided colon cancer.

 

Option C: Smoking is a well-established risk factor for various cancers, including colon cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While ulcerative colitis, smoking, and possibly cholecystectomy are associated with an increased risk of colon cancer, HPV is not currently recognized as a risk factor for this disease.

 

  • Worldwide, the prevalence of colorectal cancer is closely associated with the intake of red meat and particularly processed meat products (haem and N-nitroso compounds). A protective effect of dietary fibre is also suggested by epidemiological studies.

  • A long-held hypothesis is that increased roughage is associated with reduced colonic transit times that in turn reduce exposure of the mucosa to dietary carcinogens.

  • Conversely, high magnesium and calcium intake may be protective.

  • The epidemiological evidence supporting prostaglandin inhibitors, particularly aspirin, in preventing colorectal cancer is substantial. Given the potential hazards of taking long-term aspirin, the challenge is to identify individuals for whom the protective benefits outweigh the harm.

  • Other factors that increase the risk of developing colorectal cancer include inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

  • Cholecystectomy may marginally increase the risk of right-sided colon cancer.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed., Pg 1359

questions.text: Which of the following is not an extra-colonic manifestation of FAP?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Renal cell carcinoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal cell carcinoma is not commonly associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis as an extracolonic manifestation.

 

Extracolonic manifestations of FAP

  • Endodermal derivatives
    • Adenomas and carcinomas, particularly around the duodenal ampulla but also stomach, small intestine, thyroid and biliary tree
    • Gastric fundic gland polyps
    • Hepatoblastoma (option A)
  • Ectodermal derivatives
    • Epidermoid cysts (Option C)
    • Pilomatrixoma
    • Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE)
    • Brain tumours
  • Mesodermal derivatives
    • Desmoid tumours (Option D)
    • Osteomas
    • Dental problems

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg. 1357

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the treatment of carcinoma of the sigmoid colon with acute obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extended right hemicolectomy.

 

Option D:

 

Extended right hemicolectomy is performed for tumors of the right colon and is not indicated for left-sided colonic carcinoma.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: Hartman's procedure is an option for left-sided colonic obstruction where the rectum is preserved.

 

Option B: Left colectomy with anastomosis is a definitive treatment that removes the diseased section and restores bowel continuity.

 

Option C: SEMS can be used as a bridge to surgery or as palliative treatment in left-sided colonic obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extended right hemicolectomy is not used in the treatment of carcinoma of the left colon with acute obstruction; treatment options include left colectomy with or without anastomosis, or a stenting procedure.

 

Carcinoma of the left colon with obstruction can be treated in any of these ways depending on availability and expertise:

 

  1. Left colectomy and anastomosis
  2. Left colectomy with Hartmann’s
  3. SEMS
     
  • For a left-sided lesion, the decision lies between a Hartmann’s procedure and a resection and anastomosis. An on-table washout may be necessary to remove residual fecal content in the proximally obstructed bowel.
  • Alternatively, removal of the whole proximal bowel may be required if the colon is markedly distended or if there is concern regarding its viability.
  • Where endoscopic and radiological facilities are present, an obstructing left-sided lesion can often be treated initially with an expanding metal stent.

 

Overview:

 

Right hemicolectomy: For cecum and ascending colon tumors

 

Extended right hemicolectomy: For transverse colon tumors

 

Left colectomy: For descending colon/sigmoid tumors

 

Anterior resection/APR: For rectal tumors

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1362.

choices.text: 5-10% of patients will develop liver metastasis
IOC for staging is CECT abdomen and thorax
Rectum and sigmoid are the most commonly involved sites

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male came to the OPD with blood in stools and altered bowel habits. A lump was palpable in the left lower quadrant. The following barium study was obtained:

 

 

Which statement is incorrect about the following condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-10% patients will develop liver metastasis

 

Option A:

 

Image shows apple core/napkin ring deformity of descending colon suggestive of ca colon.

 

This statement is incorrect because at least 50% of patients with colorectal cancer develop liver metastasis.

 

Explanations:
 

Option B: FOLFOX is indeed a preferred chemotherapy regimen for colorectal cancer.


Option C: CECT of the abdomen and thorax is typically used for staging to assess the extent of disease and the presence of metastasis.

 

Option D: The rectum and sigmoid colon are common sites for colo-rectal cancers

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver metastasis occurs in at least 50% of colorectal cancer patients, not merely 5-10% as previously thought.

 

  • At least 50% patients develop metastasis of liver. Hematogenous spread is most commonly to the liver via the portal vein. One-third of patients will have liver metastases at the time of diagnosis and 50% will develop metastases at some point, accounting for the majority of deaths. 
  • IOC:
    • For diagnosis - Colonoscopy with biopsy
    • For staging - CECT abdomen
  • Most large bowel cancers arise from the left colon, notably the rectum (38%), sigmoid (21%) and descending colon (4%). Cancer of the caecum (12%) and ascending colon (5%) is less common but may be gradually increasing in incidence. Cancer of the transverse colon (5.5%), flexures (2–3%) and appendix (0.5%) are relatively uncommon.

 

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1359.

questions.text: In individuals with Gardner's syndrome, which is a subtype of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), which facial abnormality is most frequently encountered?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple osteoma

 

Explanation

 

Gardner’s syndrome is a variant of FAP. They are associated with:

 

  • Osteomas (Mandible is M/C)
  • Congenital hypertrophied retinal pigmented epithelium
  • Desmoid tumours
  • Sebaceous cysts   
  • Extra teeth

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple osteomas are the most common facial abnormality in Gardner's syndrome, which is a variant of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP).

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1356-57

choices.text: Colonoscopy shows the presence of pseudo-polyps
Treatment involves total proctocolectomy with ileoanal pouch anastomosis
Childhood appendectomy is a risk factor

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with tenesmus, diarrhea, and bleeding. Blood investigation shows the presence of p-ANCA, and stools show calprotectin. What is the incorrect statement concerning the above disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Childhood appendectomy is a risk factor

 

Option D:

 

Childhood appendicectomy is protective, along with smoking for ULCERATIVE COLITIS.

 

Contrary to traditional risk factors for inflammatory diseases, a childhood appendectomy is protective against the development of ulcerative colitis, not a risk factor.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: The presence of pseudo-polyps on colonoscopy is typical in patients with a history of ulcerative colitis, indicating areas of regenerative mucosa where inflammation has receded.

 

Option B: Ulcerative colitis can present at any age, but it often has a bimodal distribution, with peaks in younger adults (20s-30s) and then again in later adulthood (50s-60s).

 

Option C: For patients with severe ulcerative colitis or when there's a high risk of cancer, treatment can involve total proctocolectomy with ileoanal pouch anastomosis to remove the diseased colon and rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Childhood appendectomy is generally considered protective against the development of ulcerative colitis, contradicting the notion that it is a risk factor.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • If inflammation is confined to the rectum (proctitis), there is usually no systemic upset, and extra-alimentary manifestations are rare.

  • Features include rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and mucous discharge. The disease often remains confined to the rectum, usually with a benign course. Colitis is almost always associated with bloody diarrhea and urgency. Severe and/or extensive colitis may result in anemia, hypoproteinaemia and electrolyte disturbances

 

Colonoscopy: Where there has been remission and relapse, there may be regenerative mucosal nodules or pseudopolyps. Later, tiny ulcers may be seen that appear to coalesce. The biopsy will show crypt distortion, cryptitis/crypt abscess with marked infiltration of plasma cells within the deep lamina propria (basal plasmacytosis), and mucus depletion.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed Pg 1318-21.

questions.text: All of these are indications for surgical management of ulcerative colitis (UC) except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left-sided colitis

 

Option C:

 

Left-sided colitis implies disease restricted to the rectum and distal colon, which is usually medically controlled.

 

Left-sided colitis generally refers to disease limited to the distal colon and rectum, which is often well-controlled with medical management, hence not typically a direct indication for surgery.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Growth retardation in the context of UC can be an indication for surgery, especially when it affects the development of children or adolescents and is not manageable with medical therapy alone.

 

Option B: Steroid dependence indicates that a patient cannot maintain remission without ongoing steroid treatment, which may lead to substantial side effects, making surgery a viable option to consider for long-term management.

 

Option D: Extra-intestinal manifestations of UC can be severe and sometimes not responsive to medical therapy for the underlying bowel disease. In such cases, surgical intervention might be required to manage the systemic complications of UC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left-sided colitis alone, typically well-controlled medically, is generally not an indication for surgical intervention in ulcerative colitis.

 

The indications for surgery in UC are:

 

  • Severe or fulminating disease/toxic megacolon failing to respond to medical therapy;
  • Chronic disease with anemia, frequent stools, urgency and tenesmus;
  • Steroid-dependent disease where remission cannot be maintained without substantial doses of steroids with harmful side effects;
  • Intolerance or side effects of medical therapy required to control the disease, e.g., steroid psychosis, azathioprine induced pancreatitis;
  • Growth retardation in children or adolescents;
  • Neoplastic change: patients who have severe dysplasia or carcinoma;
  • Associated sclerosing cholangitis;
  • Extraintestinal manifestations;

 

Surgeries for UC:

 

Pan-proctocolectomy with reconstruction: This operation removes the entire colon and rectum and, by doing so, removes any risk of colorectal neoplasia or colitis symptoms.

 

Reconstruction can be in the form of:

  1. Permanent end ileostomy: indicated for patients who are not candidates for restorative surgery owing to impaired anal sphincter function, comorbidities or patient preference.
  2. Ileal pouch (J pouch) anal anastomosis: For young fit patients with good anal tone. Pouchitis is inflammation of the ileal pouch mucosa that occurs to varying degrees in up to 50% of patients who undergo IPAA for UC.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1324-26

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is brought to casualty with abdominal pain and diarrhoea. She is a known case of sigmoid diverticular disease. She undergoes laparotomy and is found to have fecal collection in the pelvis and paracolic gutters. What is her Hinchey stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

Option D

 

Hinchey 4 describes fecal peritonitis, the most severe stage where the contents of the colon have leaked into the peritoneum.

 

Explanation

 

Fecal peritonitis is Hinchey's stage 4 of diverticular perforation.

 

Option A (Hinchey 1) indicates a localized pericolic or mesenteric abscess.

 

Option B (Hinchey 2) refers to a pelvic or retroperitoneal abscess.

 

Option C (Hinchey 3) means generalized purulent peritonitis, which is an infection in the abdominal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hinchey classification is critical in diagnosing the severity of diverticulitis and guiding appropriate treatment plans, including surgical intervention. Fecal peritonitis, as indicated by Hinchey Stage 4, often requires urgent surgical management due to the high risk of widespread infection and sepsis.

 

Location: Diverticula are found in the left colon in around 75% of those over 70 years of age in the Western world. The condition is overwhelmingly found in the sigmoid colon but can affect the whole colon.

 

Complications of diverticular disease:

  • Diverticulitis

  • Abscess

  • Peritonitis

  • Intestinal obstruction

  • Haemorrhage

  • Fistula formation

 

Clinical features: Uncomplicated diverticulitis have minimal clinical features.

Diverticulitis typically presents as persistent lower abdominal pain. There may be accompanying diarrhoea or constipation. The lower abdomen is tender, especially over the left iliac fossa, but occasionally also on the right side if the sigmoid loop lies across the midline. The sigmoid colon may be tender and thickened on palpation and rectal examination may reveal a tender mass if an abscess has formed.

 

Hinchey grades of perforated diverticulitis:

 

  • Grade I - Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

  • Grade II - Pelvic abscess

  • Grade III - Purulent peritonitis

  • Grade IV - Faecal peritonitis

 

Diagnosis:

 

 

  • Spiral CT has excellent sensitivity and specificity for identifying bowel wall thickening, abscess formation and extraluminal disease and has revolutionised the assessment of complicated diverticular disease.

  • Endoscopic assessment may demonstrate the necks of diverticula within the bowel lumen in uncomplicated cases.

 

Treatment: Uncomplicated diverticulitis are managed with laxatives.

Acute diverticulitis has been traditionally treated with intravenous antibiotics and bowel rest.

 

Principles of surgical management of diverticular disease:

 

  • Hartmannâ€™s procedure is often the safest option in an emergency setting

  • Primary anastomosis (with or without proximal diversion) can be considered in selected patients

  • Elective resection may be considered for recurrent attacks or complications

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1368-69-70.

questions.text: During a colonoscopy, which finding is associated with the highest potential for malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple sessile polyps

 

Explanations:
 

  • Sessile and particularly depressed lesions have more malignant potential than pedunculated lesions.
  • The risk of malignant change increases with size, almost one-third of large (>3 cm) colonic adenomas will have an area of invasive malignancy. 
  • More the number of polyps, more is the malignant potential.
  • Recent guidelines published by the British Society of Gastroenterology have identified patients at high risk needing follow-up colonoscopy as those with either:

 

Two or more premalignant polyps, including at least one advanced colorectal polyp (defined as a serrated polyp ≥10 mm in size or containing any grade of dysplasia or as an adenoma ≥10 mm in size or containing high-grade dysplasia);

 

OR

 

Five or more premalignant polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sessile polyps are associated with a higher risk of malignant transformation compared to single or pedunculated polyps, especially as the size of the adenomas increases.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1356

choices.text: FAP and Lynch syndromes can be diagnosed using this criterion
At least one polyp diagnosed before 50 years
Tumors are verified by radiological examination

questions.text: Choose the correct statement for the Amsterdam II criteria.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) At least 2 successive generations affected

 

Option D:

 

This statement is correct and is one of the Amsterdam II criteria for the diagnosis of Lynch syndrome.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: FAP and Lynch syndromes can be diagnosed using this criterion - This is incorrect because the Amsterdam II criteria specifically relate to Lynch syndrome, not FAP.

 

Option B: At least one polyp diagnosed before 50 years - The Amsterdam II criteria involve at least one cancer (not just a polyp) diagnosed before the age of 50 years.

 

Option C: Tumors are verified by radiological examination - This is incorrect. The diagnosis of tumors in Lynch syndrome is verified by pathological examination, not just radiological examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The components of the Amsterdam II criteria for Lynch syndrome, which include at least one cancer diagnosed before 50 years, involvement of at least three family members (one of whom is a first-degree relative of the others), and that at least two successive generations are affected.

 

AMSTERDAM II criteria: (3-2-1)

 

Three or more family members with a Lynch syndrome-related cancer (colorectal, endometrial, small bowel, ureter, renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two.

 

  •  Two or more successive affected generations
  • At least one tumour diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • FAP excluded
  • Tumours verified by pathological examination

 

Because of the accelerated pathway from adenoma to cancer in Lynch syndrome those with a gene mutation should be offered 2-yearly endoscopic surveillance from age 25 years (MLH1 and MSH2 carriers) or 35 years (MSH6 carriers). 

                                                                   

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg. 1358

questions.text: Identify the marked area:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Griffith’s point

 

Option C:

 

Griffith's point is located at the splenic flexure and is a known watershed area with potentially tenuous blood supply. It is the correct identifier for the marked area in the image.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Sudeck's point refers to the critical point of blood supply at the rectosigmoid junction, which is not indicated in the image.

 

Option B: The Arc of Riolan is an anastomotic vessel that connects the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) with the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA), but it is not what is marked in the image.

 

Option D: Drummond's arcade is the marginal artery along the colon that provides blood supply close to the colonic wall but does not refer to a specific watershed area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Griffith's point is the watershed area located at the splenic flexure of the colon, which is vulnerable to ischemia in cases of acute mesenteric ischemia.

 

Watershed areas of the colon:

 

Rectosigmoid junction - Sudeck’s point

 

Arc of Riolan: Anastomosis between SMA and IMA

 

Marginal arcade of Drummond: Anastomotic branches of colic arteries near the wall.

 

  • Peripheral branches of the superior and inferior mesenteric vessels usually anastomose, resulting in a continuous vascular supply along the colon, referred to as the marginal artery of Drummond. This vessel is often the key blood supply to the vascular arcades, ensuring adequate perfusion of a colonic anastomosis; however, blood flow in the ‘watershed’ area of the splenic flexure representing the junction of the embryological midgut and hindgut may be tenuous.
  • Sudden occlusion of the inferior mesenteric artery may leave the area of the splenic flexure poorly perfused, leading to an ischaemic colitis

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1354

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman undergoes a screening colonoscopy after her family doctor's recommendation. She has no family history of colon cancer. A single polyp was found during the colonoscopy and a biopsy was taken. Which of the following findings in the biopsy will carry the highest risk of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Villous adenoma

 

Option A:

 

Adenomatous polyps are the most common polyps with malignant potential. The risk of malignancy is dependent on histology, morphology and size. Tubular adenomas have the lowest risk, with increasing risk as villous features predominate. Sessile and particularly depressed lesions have more malignant potential than pedunculated lesions 

 

Villous adenomas have a higher risk of malignancy due to their villous tissue architecture, which is more likely to harbor cancerous changes compared to other polyp types.

 

Explanations:
 

Option B: Hyperplastic polyps are typically considered to have a very low risk of malignancy and are often found incidentally.

 

Option C: Tubular adenomas do have a potential for malignancy, but less so than villous adenomas, especially when small and without dysplasia.

 

Option D: Inflammatory polyps are usually associated with inflammatory bowel disease and are not typically precancerous, though they can occur alongside dysplastic changes in chronic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Villous adenomas have the highest risk of malignancy among the polyp types due to their histological structure.

 

Reference: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1355

questions.text: A newborn presents with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, and bilious vomiting. The contrast enema picture is as follows. What is the investigation of choice to diagnose the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suction Rectal biopsy

 

Option C:

 

This is a case of Hirschsprung disease /congenital megacolon.

 

The picture shows a contrast enema with a narrow aganglionic segment, a cone, and dilated proximal bowel.

 

Suction Rectal biopsy is the definitive test for Hirschsprung disease because it can demonstrate the absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexuses.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: CT scan can visualize the bowel anatomy, but it is not diagnostic for Hirschsprung disease.

 

Option B: Colonoscopy allows direct visualization of the bowel but cannot diagnose Hirschsprung disease as it does not assess for the absence of ganglion cells.

 

Option D: MR Defecography is used to visualize pelvic floor function and is not used in the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suction Rectal biopsy is the standard diagnostic test for Hirschsprung disease, as it can confirm the absence of enteric ganglion cells.

 

Pathology: Aganglionic bowel fails to relax, causing a functional obstruction.

 

Presentation: Hirschsprung’s disease presents with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension and bilious vomiting

 

Diagnosis: Suction Rectal biopsy > Full-thickness biopsy

 

Surgery: Swenson, Duhamel, Yancey–Soave and trans-anal ‘pull-through’ procedures.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery 28th edition pg 269-270

choices.text: It is an autosomal dominant condition
Lifetime risk of developing colorectal cancer is 80%
Amsterdam and Bethesda criteria can be used to diagnose Lynch syndrome
The most common site involved in cancer formation is the distal colon in Lynch syndrome

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement concerning Lynch syndrome.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The most common site involved in cancer formation is the distal colon in Lynch syndrome.

 

Option D:

 

Lynch syndrome, previously known as hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is characterized by an increased risk of colorectal cancer and also cancers of the endometrium, ovary, stomach and small intestine, urinary tract, pancreas, prostate, and kidney. It is an autosomal dominant condition due to mutation in DNA Mismatch repair (MMR) genes.

 

Incorrect, in Lynch syndrome, colorectal cancer most commonly develops in the proximal colon, not the distal colon.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: Correct, Lynch syndrome is indeed an autosomal dominant condition.

 

Option B: Correct, the lifetime risk of developing colorectal cancer in Lynch syndrome is around 80%.

 

Option C: Correct, the Amsterdam and Bethesda criteria are a set of guidelines used to identify individuals who should be further tested for Lynch syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proximal colon is the most common site of cancer formation in Lynch syndrome, contrasting with the misconception that the distal colon is predominantly affected.

 

  • The lifetime risk is 80%. Most cancers develop in the proximal colon. Females have a 30-50% lifetime risk of developing endometrial cancer.

  • Lynch syndrome was historically diagnosed based on a family history of cancer and the clinical parameters set out in the Amsterdam and Bethesda criteria.

  • Recent advances in immunohistochemistry allow for MMR proteins or MSI to be accurately identified in all colorectal tumors with subsequent genetic testing in patients and families of those proven positive.

  • Because of the accelerated pathway from adenoma to cancer in Lynch syndrome those with a gene mutation should be offered 2-yearly endoscopic surveillance from age 25 years (MLH1 and MSH2 carriers) or 35 years (MSH6 carriers).

  • PMS2 carriers should be offered 5-yearly screening beginning at age 35 years

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed Pg 1358

questions.text: In the context of colorectal cancer progression, which gene mutation is recognized as a marker indicative of the transition from a benign polyp to an invasive carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P53

 

Option A:

 

The adenoma–carcinoma sequence is not a simple stepwise progression of mutations but a complicated array of multiple genetic alterations, ultimately resulting in an invasive tumour.

 

The P53 gene mutation is associated with later stages of colorectal cancer and is considered a hallmark of tumor progression to an invasive state.

 

Explanations:

Option B: The RB gene is associated with retinoblastoma and other cancers, but it is not specifically a marker of invasion in colorectal cancer.


Option C: The KRAS gene mutation plays a role in the earlier stages of colorectal cancer progression but is not as definitive for invasion as P53.


Option D: The APC gene mutation occurs early in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence and is not a marker of invasion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The P53 gene mutation is frequently associated with the invasive phase of colorectal cancer, distinguishing it from earlier mutations such as APC and KRAS which occur in pre-invasive lesions.

 

  • Mutations of the APC gene occur in two-thirds of colonic adenomas and are thought to develop early in the carcinogenesis pathway.
  • K-ras mutations result in the activation of cell signaling pathways and are more common in larger lesions, suggesting that they are later events in mutagenesis.
  • The p53 gene is frequently mutated in carcinomas but not in adenomas and therefore thought to be a marker of invasion. 
  • Mnemonic: Order of mutations: APC->K-ras->p53 = AK53

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed., Pg. 1358

questions.text: The second most common site of hematogenous metastasis in colorectal cancer is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lungs are the second most common site of hematogenous metastases in colorectal cancer following the liver.

 

  • Lung is the second most common site of metastasis after the liver.

 

  • Haematogenous spread is most commonly to the liver via the portal vein. One-third of patients will have liver metastases at the time of diagnosis and 50% will develop metastases at some point, accounting for the majority of deaths. The lung is the next most common site of metastatic disease whereas spread to the ovaries, brain, kidney and bone is less common. 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1359

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented to the OPD with recent changes in bowel habits, weight loss, and pallor. On colonoscopy with biopsy, rectal cancer was diagnosed. The biopsy showed that the muscularis propria was breached. According to Duke’s criteria, which stage would you place him at?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage B

 

Option B:

 

Stage B involves breach of the muscularis propria without lymph node involvement, fitting the patient's description.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: Stage A is characterized by invasion into mucosa and submucosa


Option C: Stage C indicates that lymph nodes are involved, which is not mentioned in this case.


Option D: Stage D, although not originally described by Dukes, is commonly used to denote metastatic disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colorectal cancer breaching the muscularis propria without lymph node involvement is classified as Duke's stage B.

 

Dukes’ staging for colorectal cancer.

 

  • A: Invasion of but not breaching the muscularis propria
  • B: Breaching the muscularis propria but not involving lymph nodes
  • C: Lymph nodes involved

 

NOTE: Dukes himself never described a stage D, but this is often used to describe metastatic disease

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. 1359

questions.text: According to 8th AJCC classification of colorectal cancers, tumor deposits in the visceral peritoneum is staged as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T4a

 

Explanation

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor deposits in the visceral peritoneum are classified as T4a in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for colorectal cancer.      

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed., Pg. 1360

choices.text: MAP is considered a diagnosis if the APC variant is not identified
Colonoscopy should be performed every 2 years
Surveillance for duodenal adenomas should also be done

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement concerning MYH-Associated Polyposis (MAP).
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It’s an autosomal dominant condition

 

Option A:

 

The appearance of MAP can be similar to FAP but it is inherited as an autosomal recessive phenotype and predisposes individuals to multiple colonic polyps.

 

MAP is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, not autosomal dominant.

 

Explanations:

 

Option B: Correct, if no APC pathogenic variant is identified in a polyposis patient, MAP should be considered, and MUTYH gene testing is indicated.

 

Option C: Correct, individuals with MAP should undergo colonoscopic surveillance every 2 years.

 

Option D: Correct, surveillance for duodenal adenomas is also recommended in individuals with MAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MYH-Associated Polyposis (MAP) is an autosomal recessive condition, not autosomal dominant, which is characterized by a predisposition to multiple colonic polyps and an associated increased risk for colorectal cancer.

 

  • If an APC pathogenic variant is not identified in an individual with colonic polyposis, molecular genetic testing of MUTYH should be considered. There is an increased risk of colorectal cancer of between three and six-fold depending on the particular MUTYH mutation.
  • Colonoscopy should be performed every 2 years.
  • Colectomy is required when the number and/or characteristics of the polyps do not allow complete endoscopic resection or malignancy is diagnosed. Surveillance for duodenal adenomas is recommended.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg. 1357

choices.text: This disease begins at the rectum and moves proximally
The fulminant disease is characterized by more than 10 bowel movements in a day
The disease is limited to mucosa and submucosa only

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with tenesmus and rectal bleeding. On endoscopy, the following picture was obtained. What is the FALSE statement concerning the above condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smoking is a risk factor.

 

Given colonoscopy is of ulcerative colitis, showing continuous ulcers (no skip areas). Smoking is protective for UC.

 

Contrary to many other health conditions where smoking is a risk factor, in ulcerative colitis, smoking has been observed to have a protective effect.

 

Explanations:
 

Option A: The characteristic pattern of inflammation in ulcerative colitis begins at the rectum and typically extends proximally in a continuous manner.

 

Option C: Fulminant colitis, a severe form of ulcerative colitis, can present with more than 10 bowel movements per day, often with systemic symptoms and a risk of toxic megacolon.


Option D: Ulcerative colitis affects only the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon, which differentiates it from Crohn's disease that can involve the entire thickness of the bowel wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smoking is not a risk factor for ulcerative colitis; it is, in fact, inversely associated, with a protective effect reported in some studies.

 

  • UC is characterised by mucosal inflammation of the large bowel, always involving the rectum (proctitis) and extending to involve varying degrees of more proximal colon (colitis). When the entire colon and rectum are involved (pancolitis), some patients may also have a degree of â€˜backwash ileitisâ€™, in which there is secondary inflammation in the terminal ileum.

 

Truelove and Witt severity of UC:

 

  1. Mild <4 stools/day, Moderate 4 to 6/day, no systemic illness

  2. Severe > 6 stools/d, hypoalbuminemia, systemic illness

  3. Fulminant >10/d, toxic megacolon

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg. 1319

choices.text: Screening test of choice is flexible colonoscopy
Current protocols for colonic surgery permit the use of preoperative bowel preparation
The most important determinant of prognosis is tumor stage

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement of colorectal cancers.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Screening test of choice is flexible colonoscopy

 

Option A:

 

In the UK, screening Fecal test is offered every 2 years to men and women aged 60–74 years, followed by colonoscopy in those who test positive. Originally a guaiac-based test was used, which detects peroxidase-like activity of faecal haematin. More recently the faecal immunochemical test (FIT) has been introduced. This test is more accurate and easier to complete than the old faecal occult blood test.

 

Explanations:
 

Option B: There is evidence that preoperative mechanical bowel preparation in combination with preoperative oral antibiotics not only reduces surgical site infection rates but also rates of anastomotic leak, postoperative ileus, reoperation and even mortality.

 

Option C: Overall, 5-year survival for colorectal cancer is approximately 58%. While numerous factors may predict prognosis the most important determinant is tumour stage and, in particular, lymph node status. Patients with disease confined to the bowel wall (TNM stage 1, Dukes’ stage A) will usually have a cure by surgical resection alone and around 95% will have disease-free survival at 5 years.

 

Option D: Hepatic and pulmonary metastases can be resected and series have demonstrated 5-year survival of around 40% in resectable disease. CT, MRI and positron emission tomography (PET) scanning are all used to identify colorectal metastases and assess patients’ suitability for further resection.

 

Educational objective:

 

The key incorrect statement regarding colorectal cancer is that flexible colonoscopy is the screening test of choice. In fact, screening in the UK involves a fecal immunochemical test (FIT) offered biennially to specific age groups, with colonoscopy following a positive FIT result.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1360, 1363, 1364.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient was brought to the casualty with a high fever and pain in the abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Toxic megacolon

 

Option B:

 

Toxic megacolon is a sequalae of ulcerative colitis. It presents with acute pain and distention of abdomen. There is severe tenderness and absent bowel sounds over the transverse colon. It is diagnosed on X-rays and CECT abdomen.

 

Toxic megacolon is characterized by extreme dilation of the colon, abdominal pain, and systemic toxicity, and is a known complication of inflammatory bowel disease, fitting the patient's history and symptoms.

 

Explanations:

Option A: Intestinal perforation is a serious complication of several abdominal conditions, often presenting with acute onset of severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis, but the radiograph would typically show free air under the diaphragm.


Option C: Pneumatosis intestinalis presents with multiple air pockets within the wall of the intestine on imaging, which is not described here.


Option D: Sigmoid volvulus would show a distinctive twisted loop of bowel on imaging and is less likely in a patient with a history of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is important to understand the clinical and radiographic signs of toxic megacolon which a severe complication of ulcerative colitis is characterized by colonic dilation, abdominal pain, and systemic symptoms.

 

  • Approximately 5% of patients present with acute severe (fulminant) colitis. Intensive medical treatment leads to remission in 70% but the remainder require urgent surgery. Toxic dilatation should be suspected in patients who develop severe abdominal pain and confirmed by the presence on a plain abdominal radiograph of a colon with a diameter of more than 6 cm.

  • Colonic perforation is a grave complication with a mortality rate of 40%. Steroids may mask the physical signs

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1320.

questions.text: What is the most common extra intestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arthropathy

 

Option B:

 

Arthropathy (15%) is the most common extra intestinal manifestation of UC in the form of sacroiliitis/ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Erythema nodosum is a condition that presents as red and painful nodules on the skin, particularly on the shins, and is one of the skin manifestations associated with ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B: Arthropathy in the context of UC often refers to joint pain or swelling, which can be a manifestation of conditions like sacroiliitis or ankylosing spondylitis, which are more common in UC than the other listed conditions.

 

Option C: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a serious liver condition that can be associated with UC but is not as common as joint issues. It leads to inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts.

 

Option D: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare skin disorder characterized by painful ulcers, typically more uncommon than arthropathy in the context of UC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arthropathy is the most frequent extra-intestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis, affecting around 15% of patients.

 

Other manifestations include:

 

  • Skin: pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum

  • Eyes: episcleritis, uveitis

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis

 

Note: Though cholangiocarcinoma is associated, the risk does not reduce after colectomy.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1320

choices.text: Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of syncope. He said he felt dizzy during defecation and noticed gross bleeding in the pan. Screening done 2 months back was negative for colon cancer. There is no history of recent weight loss. What is the likely colonoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon

 

Option D:

 

Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon, characteristic of angiodysplasia, would account for the painless rectal bleeding and are associated with aortic stenosis (Heyde’s syndrome).

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Early-stage carcinoma of the colon is typically associated with weight loss and changes in bowel habits but less likely with a negative recent colonoscopy.

 

Option B: Sigmoid diverticulitis usually presents with left lower quadrant pain and fever, less commonly with significant bleeding unless complicated by perforation.

 

Option C: Microscopic colitis typically presents with watery diarrhea without visible blood and is not associated with the described vascular malformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients over the age of 60, particularly those with aortic stenosis, angiodysplasia is a common cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding and can be identified on colonoscopy as dilated tortuous submucosal veins, especially in the right colon.

 

Angiodysplasia: Angiodysplasia is a vascular malformation that commonly causes hemorrhage from the colon in patients over the age of 60. The malformations consist of dilated tortuous submucosal veins.

 

Clinical features: In the majority of cases, the symptoms are subtle and patients can present with anemia. About 10–15% have brisk bleeds, which may present as melaena or significant rectal bleeding. Many patients in whom rectal bleeding has been attributed to diverticular disease have probably bled from angiodysplasia. There is an association with aortic stenosis (Heyde’s syndrome).

 

Investigation: Colonoscopy may show the characteristic lesion in the right colon. The lesions are only a few millimetres in size and appear as reddish, raised areas at endoscopy. CT angiography shows the site and extent of the lesion by a ‘blush’ of contrast, provided bleeding is more rapid than 1 mL/min.

 

Management: CT angiography allows not only localization if bleeding is rapid but also therapeutic embolization. If angiography fails or is unavailable, careful colonoscopy (with copious lavage) may allow cauterisation to be carried out and an argon laser can be helpful. In severe uncontrolled bleeding, surgery becomes necessary.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1370-71.

choices.text: The most common site of diverticula is the rectum
Diverticula are usually an incidental diagnosis
Imaging like barium enema shows a “Saw-tooth” appearance
Pneumaturia occurs due to colo-vesical fistula

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about colonic diverticular disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The most common site of diverticula is the rectum

 

Option A:

 

Diverticula are found in the left colon in around 75% of those over 70 years of age in the Western world. The condition is overwhelmingly found in the sigmoid colon but can affect the whole colon. In South East Asia right-sided diverticular disease is more common. The rectum has a complete muscular coat and a wider lumen and is thus very rarely affected.

 

Explanations:

 

Option B: Diverticula are most often asymptomatic (diverticulosis) and found incidentally. but they can present clinically with sepsis or haemorrhage.

 

Option C: Diverticula appear as “Saw-tooth” on contrast imaging

 

 

Option D: The presentation of a fistula resulting from diverticular disease depends on the site. The most common colo-vesical fistula results in recurrent urinary tract infections and pneumaturia (flatus in the urine) or even feces in the urine.

 

Educational objective:

 

Colonic diverticuli are acquired false diverticuli which commonly affect sigmoid colon and descending colon. Rectum is spared due to its thick muscular coat.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1368-69.
